I.  THE PROPOSAL  
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  for  the  Guangxi  Baise  Integrated  Urban  Environment 
Improvement Project.1 The project will improve urban infrastructure and services, as well as the 
environment of Dongsun subdistrict of Baise, a city in the Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region 
(GZAR). By providing roads, bridges, and associated infrastructure including water supply and 
wastewater and storm water collection systems; river rehabilitation and flood control; upgraded 
community  facilities;  and  capacity  building,  the  project  will  contribute  to  urban  renewal  and 
sustainable development in Dongsun. 2 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Rationale 
2.  Baise is in western GZAR and has an urban population of 260,000. Baise is one of the 14 
key national poverty areas in the PRC. Dongsun subdistrict is a peri-urban area 4 kilometers (km) 
west of Baise’s urban center.3 The Dongsun subdistrict industrial area was developed during 
1950–1960, when a number of state-owned enterprises built factories and housing for its workers 
in  the  southwest  of  Baise  along  the  Youjiang  River.4 During  1980–1990,  these  plants’  low 
production efficiency became increasingly apparent as subsidies to state-owned enterprises were 
removed  and  production  costs  were  brought  closer  to  market  norms.  Consequently,  facilities 
closed, and others were sold or leased to private enterprises. Today, only the coal mine, fertilizer 
factory, and motor plant continue to operate in Dongsun.  
 
3.  After  more  than  50  years  of  state-led  industrialization,  Dongsun  shoulders  heavy 
socioeconomic  and  environmental  burdens.  Since  2008,  employment has  shrunk  as factories 
closed and workers were laid  off or took early retirement options. Local residents are highly 
dissatisfied with inadequate social services and infrastructure.5 First, current flood control capacity 
in the project area is unable to protect against a flood that occurs once in 50 years, which is the 
standard requirement. Second, without a wastewater collection system, factories and residential 
areas discharge untreated wastewater directly into the Dongsun stream, which flows into the 
Youjiang river and thus pollutes Baise’s main source of drinking water. Third, the existing urban 
road network in Dongsun is inadequate for planned population growth, the resulting increased 
activity in residential and commercial areas, and proper links with other subdistricts.6 Fourth, solid 
waste transportation capacity must urgently be increased to mitigate the environmental pollution 
currently  caused  by  uncontrolled  solid  waste  dumping.  Further,  former  and  current  industrial 
facilities have left Dongsun with localized moderate soil contamination. The detailed environmental 
site assessment7undertaken under phase 1 of project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) 
described the contamination and appropriate measures to clean it up.8   
                                                
1  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
2  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) provided project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA): ADB. 2011. Technical 
Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for Preparing the Guangxi Baise Integrated Urban Environment 
Rehabilitation  Project. Manila. 
3  Dongsun subdistrict covers 2.8 square kilometers. 
4  The industrial area included a coal mine, nitrogen fertilizer factory, motor plant, electrical power plant, and paper mill. 
For more than 50 years, these industries constituted, along with government administration, much of the urban 
economy of Baise.  
5  A detailed social development assessment undertaken by the China Center for Urban Development highlighted the 
challenge to consolidate and improve fragmented social services in the project area through urban redevelopment.  
6  Damaged pavement and poor alignment undermine road safety and push up road maintenance and vehicle operating 
costs. 
7  Y.Y. Gong., L. Jiang, and W. H. Zhang. 2011. Guangxi Baise Integrated Urban Environment Improvement–Baise 
Industrial Park Redevelopment Demo Project. Manila (final report submitted to ADB to assess the extent and location

2 
 
4.   The Baise Municipal Government (BMG) is modernizing its industry and developing three 
new industrial parks with higher environmental management standards. It decided to close down 
the remaining industrial operations in Dongsun, relocate some factories to the new industrial parks, 
and prioritize urban and economic regeneration in Dongsun. The Baise City Urban Master Plan, 
2010–2030  has  designated  Dongsun  as  a  residential  district  with  green  and  environmentally 
friendly facilities. In 2011–2012, the BMG contracted Tongji University to prepare the Urban Design 
Plan and the Control Plan to establish the legal basis for improving Dongsun from 2013 to 2030.9 
The plans called for creating a mixed-use community with residential, commercial, tourism, and 
recreational  areas.  The  population  at  completion  in  2030  is  projected  to  be  34,000.10 The 
identification of polluted sites and the land-use plan recommended under phase 1 of the PPTA are 
accurately mapped in the Control Plan prepared by Tongji University. Sensitive land uses, such as 
for schools and housing, were restricted to uncontaminated land. 
 
5.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will play a vital role in redeveloping Dongsun by 
financing  trunk  infrastructure  improvements  and  rehabilitating  waterfronts  along  the  Dongsun 
stream and Youjiang river. With all major arterial roads and associated water and wastewater 
piped networks financed under the project, the urban infrastructure built through the ADB project 
will catalyze private investment in residential, commercial, and mixed-used development. The 
project fits well with recent objectives of the Government of the PRC to balance future urbanization 
with greater attention to developing small and medium-sized cities. ADB’s current and future 
operations focus on small and medium-sized cities in the central and western PRC.  
 
6.  The  project  will  support  private  sector  participation  by  creating  additional  demand  for 
privatized wastewater treatment services. The existing build-operate-transfer wastewater treatment 
plant in Baise will soon enter the second phase of capital investment. The 12,000 new customers 
in  Dongsun  that  the  project  will  connect  to  the  wastewater  treatment  plant  will  enhance  the 
commercial viability of that investment.11  
 
7.  The project is envisaged playing a demonstration role for other cities on how to regenerate 
strategically located urban land now burdened with outdated and uneconomic industries. Many 
similar industrial areas developed under the state-run enterprise industrial model during 1950–
1960 still exist in cities across the PRC. These areas are characterized by production inefficiency, 
environmental degradation, unhealthy living conditions, and inadequate urban infrastructure. The 
multisector integrated approach to urban redevelopment adopted by the project can be adopted by 
other local governments to transform environmentally degraded neighborhoods into livable mixed-
use residential areas. 
                                                
of contamination at industrial sites, which called for further site investigation and the dismantling of factories and 
cleaning up of the sites). 
8  The PPTA was implemented in two phases. Phase 1 assessed industrial pollution to facilitate project scoping and 
developed environmental management guidelines for the dismantling and cleaning up of the industrial sites in 
Dongsun. Phase 2 was conventional PPTA to prepare the proposed project. 
9  The ADB-assisted Urban Knowledge Hub at Tongji University was launched in March 2010 and extended to November 
2017. Outputs include (i) innovative municipal and environmental infrastructure, especially solid waste and wastewater 
management; (ii) regional planning, city cluster development, and economic corridors; (iii) climate change adaptation, 
energy efficiency, and clean development mechanism; (iv) urban expansion and renewal; (v) urban transport; and (vi) 
local government and municipal infrastructure finance. 
10 The population figure is based on functional zoning assumptions about the intensity of development (the ratio of built 
space to open space), plot coverage and building heights, the total built area, and average occupancy rates. 
11 Currently, there is no wastewater collection system in Dongsun. The project will construct a wastewater collection trunk 
line to take wastewater to the existing build-operate-transfer wastewater treatment plant in Baise  and this will sustain 
water quality in the local river at Class III, in the PRC water quality standards (Class I to V , Class III is the minimum 
water quality required for municipal water supply).

3 
 
8.  Fit with ADB strategy. The project supports environmentally sustainable and inclusive 
economic growth, which is a priority of ADB’s Strategy 2020.12 It aligns with ADB’s PRC country 
partnership strategy, 2011–2015, which supports the government’s strategic goal of building an 
economically developed society by helping to foster inclusive growth and promoting environmental 
sustainability.13 The project will remove infrastructure constraints, address environmental concerns, 
promote sustainable economic growth, and support community development in Dongsun and more 
broadly in Baise. It conforms with ADB’s Urban Operational Plan, which fosters competitive, green, 
and inclusive cities,14 and is consistent with the PRC’s Twelfth Five-Year Plan, 2011–2015, which 
promotes  environment-friendly  and  resource-efficient  urban  development  and  supports  the 
development of the western region. At the local level, the project is consistent with Baise’s National 
Economic  and  Social  Development  Twelfth  Five-Year  Plan,  2011–2015,  which  emphasizes 
economic restructuring and urban development and upgrading. 
 
9.  Continuity of development initiatives and incorporated lessons from GZAR. Project 
design incorporates lessons from previous ADB-financed urban development projects in GZAR and 
the  PRC,  as  well  as  relevant  ADB  evaluation  reports.15 In  particular,  the  project  will  support 
capacity development with a special focus on improving awareness of ADB policy and procedural 
requirements  to  facilitate  a  smooth  start  to  implementation  and  compliance  with  safeguards 
requirements, and on strengthening the long-term sustainability of facilities built under the project. 
Further,  the  project  will  build  institutional  capacity  in  the  agencies  involved  in  project 
implementation and enable future operation and maintenance (O&M) units. 
 
10.  Innovative  features.  The  special  features  of  the  proposed  project  include  (i)  linkage 
between ADB’s knowledge work and sovereign operations as the ADB-supported Tongji University 
Knowledge Hub was engaged by the BMG to prepare the Urban Design Plan and the Control Plan, 
(ii) a focus on redeveloping one geographical area of a city with a broad range of infrastructure and 
environmental interventions, and (iii) community upgrading and development to enhance social 
impacts. Basic social infrastructure will be provided to meet the needs of local residents. At the 
same time, building the capacity of an existing rural community group and of the BMG will enable 
effective interaction between local residents and municipal authorities during resettlement, housing 
delivery, and economic development. This feature will include (i) investment in social infrastructure 
such  as  a  community  center,  farmer’s  market,  and  waste  transfer  station;  (ii)  community 
development to strengthen the ability of the Dongsun Subdistrict Neighborhood Committee to 
represent the existing population, a mix of rural residents and state workers, while dealing with the 
BMG during redevelopment on issues related to resettlement housing delivery, local economic 
development planning, and workforce training; and (iii) policy and regulatory development to help 
the BMG develop processes and institutional mechanisms that integrate public participation into 
community development planning. 
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The  project  impact  will  be  the  development  of  Dongsun  subdistrict  of  Baise  into  an 
environment-friendly, inclusive, and livable  urban area. The project outcome will be improved 
urban infrastructure and services in Dongsun. 
 
                                                
12 ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. Manila. 
13 ADB. 2012. Country Partnership Strategy: People’s Republic of China, 2011–2015. Manila. 
14 ADB. 2012. Urban Operational Plan. Manila. 
15 ADB. 2010. Special Evaluation Study on Post-Completion Monitoring and Sustainability. Manila.

4 
C.  Outputs 
12.  The  Dongsun  Urban  Design  Plan  and  the  Control  Plan  emphasize  the  integrated 
construction of urban infrastructure. Accordingly, the project includes integrated components or 
outputs in the form of urban infrastructure and associated “soft-side” interventions. The design of 
each component supports the overarching objectives of improving the environment in Dongsun 
and enabling the development of a safe, inclusive, and livable residential community. The project 
has four outputs, which are summarized below and further detailed in the project administration 
manual (PAM).16   
 
(i)  Urban river rehabilitation and flood control. The provision of 4.2 km of new 
embankment along the left bank of the Youjiang River will protect Dongsun from 
once-in-50-years flooding, and the improvement of 4.0 km of the Dongsun stream 
will protect Dongsun from once-in-20-year flooding and  improve its flow capacity to 
protect against urban waterlogging.  
(ii)  Urban transport and associated infrastructure. The construction of 11.3 km of 
roads, including four bridges across the Dongsun stream, 10.2 km of integrated 
roadside water supply pipeline, 9.85 km of storm water pipeline, and 7.95 km of 
wastewater collection pipelines, and of two bus terminals, will improve Dongsun’s 
urban infrastructure. 
(iii)  Community  upgrading  and  development.  Integrated  community  development 
planning will include (a) the construction of a 850 square meter (m2) community 
service center, a 3,000 m2 market for agricultural trade, and a solid waste transfer 
station with a handling capacity of 50 tons/day; (b) the strengthening of the Dongsun 
Neighborhood Committee;17 and (c) policy and regulatory development.  
(iv)  Capacity  building  and  project  management.  Institutional  development  and 
capacity  building  in  integrated  urban  development, 18  ecological  restoration, 
community  development,  the  dismantling  of  obsolete  industrial  facilities,  the 
assessment and remediation of contaminated sites, and project management will 
contribute to the effective implementation of the project and the sustainable O&M of 
project facilities. 
 
D.  Investment and Financing Plans  
13.  The project is estimated to cost $169.5 million (Table 1). 
 
   
                                                
16 Project Administration Manual (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
17 Activities in this component will ensure community representation in further urban and economic development planning 
regarding  issues  such  as  the  location  and  provision  of  basic  services,  access  to  training  and  employment 
opportunities, and community maintenance. 
18 An integrated feature is the laying of water supply pipelines and wastewater collection trunk lines along urban road 
alignments.

5

a  Includes taxes and duties of about $6.66 million to be financed from government and ADB loan resources. The 
principles followed in determining the amount of taxes and duties to be financed by ADB are (i) the amount being 
within reasonable country thresholds; (ii) the amount representing 4.75% of base cost and not an excessive share of 
the project investment plan; (iii) taxes and duties applying only to ADB-financed expenditures, and (iv) the financing of 
the taxes and duties being relevant to the success of the project. 
b  In March 2013 prices. 
c  Physical contingencies computed at 10% of base costs. Price contingencies computed at an average of 1.9% for

d  Includes interest and commitment charges. Interest during implementation for the ADB loan has been computed at the

premium of 0.20%. Commitment charges for the ADB loan are 0.15% per year to be charged on the undisbursed loan 
amount. 
Source: Asian Development Bank estimates.  
 
14.  The government has requested a loan of $80 million from ADB’s ordinary capital resources 
to help finance the project. The loan will have a 25-year term, including a grace period of 5 years,19 
an  annual  interest  rate  determined  in  accordance  with  ADB's  London  interbank  offered  rate 
(LIBOR)-based lending facility, a commitment charge of 0.15% per year (the interest and other 
charges during construction to be capitalized during the loan), and such other terms and conditions 
set forth in the draft loan and project agreements. The loan will cover civil works, equipment, project 
management consulting services, capacity building, and financing charges during implementation. 
The Baise Development and Investment Group (BDIG), BMG, and PRC have assured ADB that 
counterpart funding  will  be  provided  in  a  timely  manner,  including  any  additional  counterpart 
funding required for any shortfall of funds or cost overruns, including post-project recurrent funding. 
The project financing plan is summarized in Table 2 and detailed in the PAM (footnote 16).  
 
15.  The PRC is the borrower of the loan. The PRC will make the loan available through the 
Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region Government (GZARG) to the BMG on the same terms and 
conditions as those for the ADB loan. As the end borrower, the BMG will assume foreign exchange 
and interest rate variation risks for the ADB loan. The flow of funds and relending arrangements 
are documented in the PAM (footnote 16).

6 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 3 and described in detail in the 
PAM. The BMG has ongoing experience in implementing ADB projects.20

17.  The project includes funding for international and national consulting services to support the 
executing and implementing agencies, in addition to building capacity in implementing agency and 
O&M units.21 The terms of reference for the consulting services are in the PAM (footnote 16).

7 
III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
18.  The  project  will  directly  benefit  the  projected  34,000  residents  of  Dongsun  in  2030.22 
Indirect beneficiaries, conservatively estimated at 75,000, include the residents of other urban 
subdistricts of Baise who will benefit from urban environmental improvement. The project will 
improve transport, environmental, and social infrastructure in Dongsun through river rehabilitation 
and flood control works, the construction of roads and associated piped infrastructure, and the 
provision of social infrastructure. Net environmental benefits include mitigated flooding risk, better 
solid waste management, and reduced pollution in surface waters. 
 
A.  Technical 
19.  All project components are designed taking into account local circumstances, topography, 
seismology, and climate, in accordance with the PRC design guidelines and local regulations. The 
designs for all project works are based on tested and proven principles, suitable for the local 
climate, and executable using local construction expertise. River rehabilitation will greatly improve 
the city’s resilience under climate change,23 while significantly enhancing the urban environment. 
Capacity building to ensure the sustainability of O&M will be financed under the loan.  
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
20.  Economic analysis. The economic analysis examined the economic viability of each type 
of project intervention and the viability of the project as a whole. Project interventions are expected 
to generate the following economic benefits: (i) savings in vehicle operating costs; (ii) passenger 
time savings; (iii) road safety benefits; (iv) road maintenance savings; (v) an improved environment 
brought about by the restoration of the Youjiang river and Dongsun stream, as well as better flood 
protection for households in the project area; (vi) higher land values brought about by riverbank 
stabilization, soil protection, and solid waste removal; and (vii) higher income brought about by (a) 
the increase in well-spaced stalls and display areas in the new market, (b) better lighting and 
ventilation, (c) more efficient sewerage and solid waste disposal systems, (d) greater shopping 
convenience, (e) wider consumer choice, and (f) more sanitary market conditions. The project 
economic internal rate of return is estimated at 16.49% and is generally robust when subjected to 
standard sensitivity analysis.  
 
21.  Financial sustainability analysis. Financial sustainability was analyzed to assess fiscal 
sustainability and the capacity of the BMG to repay the debt. The trends of economic growth and 
total revenues and expenditures were analyzed.  Annual funding to be made available during 
implementation  ranges from  CNY51.19  million  in  2018  to  CNY172.21  million  in  2015, for  an 
average of CNY111.70 million over 5 years. Average annual counterpart funding equals 0.41% of 
projected revenues during implementation. Annual forecast O&M and debt service is 0.21% of 
projected annual revenues in 2019, the first year of ADB loan repayment. The analysis concludes 
that the financial burden imposed by the project is relatively small and that counterpart financing 
and  loan  repayments  can  be  covered  under  the  government  budget.  These  results  indicate 
acceptable fiscal risk, as it is expected that BMG financial revenues will grow in line with economic 
development. Financial analysis of the water and wastewater pipeline installation portion of the 
urban roadwork indicates that these revenue-generating subcomponents are financially viable. The 
overall financial internal rate of return is estimated at 5.70%, higher than the weighted average cost 
of capital estimated at 1.78% for wastewater handling and 1.82% for water supply. 
 
                                                
22 Includes about 8,700 current residents and 25,300 new residents.  
23 Water level calculations required for the design of river embankments and the revision of the flood emergency 
preparedness and response mechanism will consider the impacts of future climate change.

8 
C.  Governance 
22.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained with the GZARG 
and the municipal governments. Financial management assessment concluded that the BDIG and 
the BPMO have general experience in managing foreign-financed projects, including ADB-financed 
projects, but still require significant training and support on ADB policies and procedures, including 
procurement, disbursement, and project management. The GZAR Provincial Finance Department, 
which will operate and administer the imprest account, has extensive experience administering 
projects financed by ADB and other foreign sources. It was agreed that the implementing agency 
would strengthen its financial management capability to manage the project by (i) establishing 
internal audit arrangements, (ii) undertaking training on ADB policy and procedural requirements, 
and (iii) seeking external financial management assistance as needed. The project’s financial 
management risk rating is low to medium after considering mitigation. The identified financial 
management risks will be closely monitored during project implementation. 
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
23.  The project is expected to create positive social benefits through improvements to the 
urban environment, infrastructure, and living conditions in Dongsun, which has a rural poverty 
incidence of 9.8% and an urban poverty incidence of 3.8%. The existing resident population is 
8,694, and the future resident population is expected to be 34,000.24 The projected 75,000 indirect 
beneficiaries include residents of other subdistricts of Baise who will use the space and facilities 
developed  in  Dongsun.  The  project  will  directly  create  1,455  jobs,  1,000  of  them  during 
construction and 455 during operation; 15,400 jobs through the development of local real estate; 
and  16,490  long-term  opportunities  in  commercial  services,  business  offices,  hotels,  and 
community  employment.  To  reinforce  the  positive  benefits  of  improved  transport,  solid  waste 
collection, and river rehabilitation, the BMG and Youjiang District Government will conduct public 
programs  on  road  safety,  public  sanitation,  and  environmental  awareness  during  project 
implementation. The component on community upgrading and development will (i) provide social 
infrastructure to residents, (ii) foster the development of a community organization to represent 
residents during the transition to a new community and help define future economic development 
and public participation, and (iii) support the BMG in creating best practice policies to address 
social risks in new area development. The social action plan will be supervised and monitored by a 
social development specialist under project management consulting services.   
 
24.  Gender  benefits.  The  project  is  categorized  as  effective  gender  mainstreaming.  The 
gender analysis found that women support the project and anticipate benefits in mobility, access, 
safety  and  security,  employment,  an  improved  living  environment,  and  more  effective  public 
participation and representation in local development planning. A gender action plan has been 
prepared to (i) enhance women’s participation in project activities; (ii) provide gender-sensitivity 
training to BDIG and BPMO staff; (iii) ensure that project decision-making bodies and capacity-
building  activities  are  gender  balanced;  and  (iv)  include  gender  targets,  indicators,  and  sex-
disaggregated data for project monitoring and evaluation. The project will (i) protect public health 
through solid waste management; (ii) improve access, safety, and mobility for women by ensuring 
pedestrian access and public transport within the new area and connecting to Baise city center; (iii) 
improve traffic safety; (iv) increase job opportunities for women; and (v) encourage women to 
participate in community development institutions. 
 
                                                
24  Based  on  the  estimate  of  Baise’s  future  population  in  Guangxi  Baise  Dongsun  Subdistrict  Integrated  Urban 
Environment Improvement Project Planning Study.

9 
E.  Safeguards 
25.  The project is classified category B for environment. An initial environmental examination, 
including  an  environmental  management  plan  (EMP)  complying  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy 
Statement (2009), was prepared and disclosed on the ADB website in June 2013. The project will 
not result in significant environment impacts. Environmental management measures defined in the 
EMP will contain the impacts to acceptable levels. While the project will not intrude on industrial 
sites, the BMG will be provided with capacity building in brownfield management to ensure that 
future site clean-up and redevelopment follow international best practice25 and comply with national 
legislation.  The  BMG  disclosed  environment  information  to  potentially  affected  people.  Any 
environmental complaints or disputes will be handled in accordance with the grievance-redress 
mechanism developed for the project.  
 
26.  The project is classified category A for resettlement and category B for indigenous peoples. 
The BMG has prepared a resettlement and ethnic minority development plan (REMDP) to cover 
land acquisition, resettlement, and indigenous peoples issues. The preliminary impact survey found 
that the project will adversely affect residents, enterprises, and stores.26 A total of 759.01 mu27 of 
land will be occupied permanently, including 547.34 mu of village collective land in Dongsun and 
211.67 mu of state-owned land. The acquisition of village collective land will adversely affect 246 
farm households with 854 members; 151 rural households with 511 members and 214 urban 
households with 673 members will lose their homes. Also, 8 enterprises with 174 operators and 
employees and 15 stores with 45 operators and employees will be affected. The project will 
permanently affect 570 households with 2,035 members, and 65 households with 258 members 
will suffer temporary impacts, for a total of 635 households with 2,293 members.28 The REMDP 
was endorsed by the BMG and disclosed to affected people through the distribution of REMDP 
information booklets published in Mandarin. Copies of the REMDP were provided to relevant local 
offices, made accessible to the affected people, and uploaded to the ADB website in June 2013.29 
The implementation of the REMDP will be monitored by the BMG internally through semiannual 
progress reports. The BPMO will engage an external monitor, who will also provide monitoring and 
evaluation reports semiannually.  
 
27.  The REMDP defines the measures to mitigate the negative impacts of resettlement on the 
local ethnic minority population. The Zhuang ethnic minority is the majority in GZAR and Baise. In 
the total population of Dongsun, 39% are Zhuang. The proportion of ethnic minorities among urban 
residents of Dongsun is, at 29%, lower than among rural residents (83%) because many former 
enterprise employees are Han from other parts of the PRC. In the Baise urban area, the Zhuang 
people live harmoniously with the Han, and most are bilingual in Zhuang and Mandarin. The 
Zhuang in Dongsun are distinct from mainstream society with respect to their customary cultural 
and  social  institutions.  Consultation  with  Zhuang  people  in  communities  in  the  project  area 
revealed that the negative impacts on ethnic minorities are resettlement and the future loss of their 
farmland to urbanization. The monitoring of the REMDP and of social and gender dimensions will 
include analysis by ethnicity.  
 
                                                
25 ASTM International. 2005. Standard Guide for Environmental Site Assessments. West Conshohocken, Pennsylvania. 
26 A census and detailed measurement survey can be conducted only upon the finalization of detailed project design. 
27 A mu is a Chinese unit of measurement (1 mu = 666.67 m2). 
28 There are households affected by both land acquisition and house demolition, and by temporary acquisition. They are 
only counted once.  
29 ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009) adjusted the terminology for involuntary resettlement, changing "affected 
persons" to "displaced persons," who were defined as persons physically and/or economically displaced by involuntary 
acquisition of land or involuntary restrictions on land use or on access to legally designated parks and protected areas. 
Although resettlement plans for ADB projects in the PRC maintain the original terminology of “affected persons,” this is 
equivalent to the new Safeguard Policy Statement definition of “displaced persons.”

10 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
28.  Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 4 and described in detail in 
the risk assessment and risk management plan.30  
 
Table 4: Summary of Risks and Mitigating Measures 
Risks  Mitigating Measures 
Lack of project coordination or  The BPMO will provide the required coordination with support 
synchronization between agencies  from project implementation consultant. The project leading 
group will provide leadership and direction and resolve major 
problems. 
Delays in land acquisition approvals and  Detailed measurement surveys will be promptly implemented. 
implementation  The availability of compensation for affected people will be 
timely. Strict operational compliance with the REMDP will be 
based on detailed design and ensure the timely provision of 
the resettlement budget.  
Failure to enforce anticorruption measures  The government has introduced an integrity program that 
    targets prevention and punishment. 
Project capacity building program to include the strengthening 
of governance mechanisms. 
Low procurement capacity and  External procurement specialists will be mobilized early to 
inexperience with ADB procurement  provide training and technical support. 
procedures 
Local rural population may not receive a  Strengthening the Dongsun neighborhood committee to 
share of future benefits commensurate with  articulate effectively the collective preferences of the 
their contribution to the project  community in terms of project benefits. 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, BMG = Baise Municipal Government, BPMO = Baise project management office, 
REMDP = resettlement and ethnic minority development plan. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
IV.  ASSURANCES  
29.  The government, the GZARG, and the BMG have assured ADB that the implementation of 
the project will conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption 
measures, safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described 
in the PAM and loan documents. The government, the GZARG and the BMG have agreed with 
ADB on certain covenants for the project, which are set forth in the loan and project agreements.  
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
30.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan of $80,000,000 
to  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  for  the  Guangxi  Baise  Integrated  Urban  Environment 
Improvement Project, from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, with interest to be determined in 
accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; for a term of 
25  years,  including  a grace  period  of  5  years;  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  as  are 
substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan and project agreements presented 
to the Board. 
 
Takehiko Nakao 
President 
 
5 September 2013 
                                                
30 Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 15 August 2013) 
 
Currency unit  –  yuan (CNY) 
 
CNY1.00  =  $0.1630   
$1.00  =  CNY6.1317   
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
BDIG  –  Baise Development & Investment Group 
BMG  –  Baise Municipal Government 
BPMO  –  Baise project management office 
EMP  –  environmental management plan 
GAP  –  gender action plan 
GZAR  –  Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region  
GZARG  –  Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region Government 
km  –  kilometer 
km2  –  square kilometer 
m2  –  square meter 
O&M  –  operation and maintenance 
PAM  –  project administration manual 
PPTA  –  project preparatory technical assistance 
PRC  –  People’s Republic of China 
REMDP  –  resettlement and ethnic minority development plan 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.  
 
 
Vice-President  S. Groff, Operations 2 
Director General  A. Konishi, East Asia Department (EARD) 
Director  D. Sharan, Urban and Social Sectors Division, EARD 
 
Team leader  S. Penjor, Lead Urban Development Specialist, EARD

M. Gupta, Principal Safeguards Specialist (Resettlement), EARD  
  A. Morel, Environment Specialist, EARD 
  C. Navarro, Senior Portfolio Management Officer, EARD 
J. Vanta, Senior Operations Assistant, EARD  
W. Walker, Senior Social Development Specialist, EARD

of any territory or area.
